title: AB 510
content: The people of California enact the following. The division will work with the California Highway Patrol on the RED Project to determine the best routing for wireless 911 calls using historical data. Repeal and amendment of certain sections in the Revenue and Taxation Code are also addressed. The Office of Emergency Services annually determines a surcharge rate to fund 911 costs, effective on January 1 of the following year. The surcharge rate is between fifteen cents ($0.15) and seventy-five cents ($0.75) per month, based on estimates for the current fiscal year. The Office of Emergency Services determines surcharge rates to fund 911 costs, including Next Generation 911 technology and services. The surcharge rate is notified to the board by October 15 each year and a summary of the proposed surcharge calculation is made available to the public and stakeholders 30 days prior to determination. Projected expenses and revenues, rationale for surcharge adjustment, impacts from surcharge collection under Part 21, and amendment to Section 41030 of the Revenue and Taxation Code. The Office of Emergency Services determines an annual surcharge rate to fund 911 costs, ranging from $0.15 to $0.75 per month. This rate includes expenses for Next Generation 911 technology and services, such as text to 911. The Office of Emergency Services prepares a summary of the proposed surcharge calculation for the Legislature and 911 Advisory Board. This act is an urgency statute to fund the efficient routing of wireless 911 calls and fully fund the emergency telephone system.
